Coenzymes: organic molecules, often vitamin-derived (e.g. NAD in respiration)

Coenzymes act as carriers of chemical groups or electrons

Biological membranes.question: Name the primary lipid that forms the basis of the fluid mosaic model. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Phospholipid

Biological membranes.question: Define the term 'fluid mosaic model'. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Membrane is a fluid phospholipid bilayer
With a mosaic of proteins (and other molecules) embedded/dispersed within it

Biological membranes.question: State one role of cholesterol in animal cell membranes. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Regulates membrane fluidity
Stabilises membrane

Biological membranes.question: Distinguish between integral (intrinsic) and peripheral (extrinsic) membrane proteins. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Integral span/are embedded in the bilayer (often transmembrane)
Peripheral are loosely attached to the surface (inner or outer leaflet)

Biological membranes.question: Explain why the phospholipid bilayer forms spontaneously in water. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Phosphate heads are hydrophilic and face aqueous environments
Fatty acid tails are hydrophobic and face inward away from water
Arrangement is energetically favourable (reduces exposure of hydrophobic tails to water)

Biological membranes.question: Describe the role of glycolipids and glycoproteins in membranes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Cell recognition/cell–cell adhesion
Receptor sites for signalling molecules

Biological membranes.question: State two features of membranes that make them 'fluid'. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Lateral movement of phospholipids
Presence of cholesterol and unsaturated fatty acids allowing flexibility

Biological membranes.question: Explain how fatty acid saturation affects membrane fluidity. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Unsaturated fatty acids introduce kinks
Reduce tight packing of tails
Increase fluidity (especially at lower temperatures)

Biological membranes.question: Define compartmentalisation in cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Separation of cellular processes into membrane-bound regions

Biological membranes.question: Give two advantages of compartmentalisation for cell function. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Creates optimal microenvironments for enzymes
Prevents interference between incompatible reactions
Concentrates substrates and enzymes

Biological membranes.question: Describe how membrane proteins are involved in cell signalling. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Receptor proteins bind specific ligands
Conformational change activates intracellular response
May trigger second messenger pathways/enzyme cascades

Biological membranes.question: Explain the role of membrane carbohydrates in cell recognition. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycocalyx patterns act as identification tags
Enable immune recognition/self–non-self discrimination

Biological membranes.question: State one membrane role in transport other than diffusion. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Endocytosis/exocytosis

Biological membranes.question: Outline how membranes contribute to energy transduction in mitochondria or chloroplasts. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Provide surfaces for electron transport chains
Create proton gradients across membranes
ATP synthase uses gradient to synthesise ATP

Biological membranes.question: Define diffusion. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Net movement of particles from higher to lower concentration

Biological membranes.question: List two factors that affect the rate of simple diffusion across membranes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Concentration gradient
Temperature
Surface area
Thickness (diffusion distance)

Biological membranes.question: Explain why large polar molecules require facilitated diffusion. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: They cannot pass through hydrophobic core of bilayer
Require specific channel or carrier proteins

Biological membranes.question: Differentiate between channel proteins and carrier proteins in facilitated diffusion. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Channels form hydrophilic pores; carriers change shape to move solute
Channels often selective for ions/water; carriers for specific molecules
Both passive and move down concentration gradient

Biological membranes.question: Define osmosis using the term water potential. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Net movement of water across a partially permeable membrane
From higher (less negative) to lower (more negative) water potential

Biological membranes.question: Describe the effect of placing plant cells in solutions of lower water potential than the cell sap. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Water leaves the cell by osmosis
Cytoplasm and membrane pull away from cell wall
Plasmolysis occurs

Biological membranes.question: Define active transport. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Movement of substances against a concentration gradient using energy (ATP)

Biological membranes.question: Explain the role of ATP in active transport via carrier proteins. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP hydrolysis provides energy
Drives conformational changes to pump solute across membrane

Biological membranes.question: Name and briefly describe two types of endocytosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Phagocytosis: uptake of large particles/cells
Pinocytosis: uptake of fluids/small solutes
Receptor-mediated endocytosis: specific ligand uptake via receptors

Biological membranes.question: Outline the process of exocytosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Vesicles fuse with plasma membrane
Contents released to extracellular space

Biological membranes.question: Explain the sodium–potassium pump as an example of active transport. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Pumps 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ into the cell per ATP hydrolysed
Maintains electrochemical gradients
Involves conformational change of an ATPase carrier

Biological membranes.question: Describe how co-transport (secondary active transport) operates. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Uses gradient of one ion (e.g., Na⁺) established by primary active transport
Co-transporter moves another solute with the ion
Does not use ATP directly in the co-transport step

Biological membranes.question: Predict the effect of increasing temperature moderately on membrane fluidity and permeability. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Increases phospholipid movement (fluidity rises)
Permeability increases (more leakage of substances)

Biological membranes.question: Explain why high temperatures can disrupt membrane structure. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Break hydrogen/weak interactions between phospholipids and proteins
Denature membrane proteins
Increase gaps in bilayer → higher permeability

Biological membranes.question: Describe the effect of organic solvents (e.g., ethanol) on membranes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Dissolve/disrupt phospholipid bilayer
Increase membrane permeability

Biological membranes.question: Outline a practical to investigate temperature effects on membrane permeability using beetroot. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Cut equal-sized beetroot discs and rinse
Incubate in water at different temperatures for fixed time
Measure pigment release using colorimeter/absorbance
Control variables (disc size, time, volume)

Biological membranes.question: Explain why aquaporins increase the rate of osmosis in certain tissues. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Provide selective channels for water
Reduce resistance compared to diffusion through bilayer

Biological membranes.question: Compare passive and active transport across membranes. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Passive: down gradient; no metabolic energy
Active: against gradient; requires ATP
Different protein involvement (channels/carriers vs pumps)

Biological membranes.question: Discuss how membrane structure supports selective permeability. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Hydrophobic core restricts polar/charged molecules
Specific transport proteins allow selective passage
Gated channels/carriers respond to stimuli
Cholesterol and lipid composition modulate permeability

Biological membranes.question: Explain how receptor-mediated endocytosis ensures specificity of uptake. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Ligands bind specific membrane receptors
Clathrin-coated pits form vesicles
Only receptor–ligand complexes internalised efficiently

Biological membranes.question: A cell is placed in a solution with water potential of −500 kPa; the cell’s cytoplasm is −300 kPa. Predict net water movement and justify. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Water moves out of the cell
From higher (−300 kPa) to lower (more negative, −500 kPa) water potential
By osmosis across the membrane

Biological membranes.question: Evaluate the statement: 'Non-polar molecules cross membranes faster than ions of similar size.' [3 marks]
mark_scheme: True because hydrophobic core favours non-polar diffusion
Ions are charged and require channels/transporters
Electrostatic interactions with water hinder ion passage

Biological membranes.question: Describe how temperature and solvent concentration together could confound a membrane permeability investigation and how to control them. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Both increase permeability via different mechanisms
Confounding if both vary between treatments
Control by keeping one constant while varying the other
Use appropriate controls and replicate measurements

Biological membranes.question: Compare and contrast diffusion, facilitated diffusion, and active transport in terms of energy use, direction, and proteins involved. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Diffusion: no energy; down gradient; no proteins required (for small non-polar)
Facilitated diffusion: no energy; down gradient; requires channels/carriers
Active transport: requires ATP; against gradient; uses pumps
All can be selective
Facilitated and active are saturable due to limited proteins
Active can establish/maintain gradients used by co-transport

Biological membranes.question: Explain how the fluid mosaic model accounts for membrane flexibility, repair, and protein mobility, and outline one experimental evidence. [6 marks]

Lipids/proteins can move to seal small tears → self-repair

Hybrid cell experiments show protein mixing

Biological membranes.question: Discuss the roles of membranes in intracellular signalling using examples of receptor types and downstream responses. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Membranes house receptors (GPCRs, enzyme-linked, ligand-gated ion channels)
Ligand binding triggers conformational change
Activates second messengers/kinase cascades
Alters gene expression/metabolic pathways
Example: insulin receptor (tyrosine kinase) → glucose uptake
Example: neurotransmitter binding opens ion channels

Biological membranes.question: Evaluate how temperature changes alter membrane fluidity and function across poikilotherms, and suggest adaptations. [6 marks]

Homeoviscous adaptation maintains optimal fluidity
Changes in protein isoforms/lipid composition
Impacts enzyme kinetics and membrane-bound processes

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Name the two main stages of the cell cycle. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Interphase
M phase (mitosis and cytokinesis)

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State what occurs during the S phase of interphase. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: DNA replication

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: List the four stages of mitosis in order. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Prophase
Metaphase
Anaphase
Telophase

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe one event that occurs during prophase. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Chromosomes condense and become visible
Nuclear envelope breaks down
Spindle fibres form

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain the role of the spindle fibres in mitosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Attach to centromeres of chromosomes
Pull sister chromatids apart to opposite poles

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State one difference between cytokinesis in animal and plant cells. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Animal: cleavage furrow forms
Plant: cell plate forms

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Give two purposes of mitosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Growth
Tissue repair
Asexual reproduction

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Define meiosis. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Reduction division producing haploid gametes from diploid cells

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain why meiosis is important in sexual reproduction. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Halves chromosome number to restore diploid state at fertilisation
Introduces genetic variation

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State the number of daughter cells produced in meiosis and whether they are genetically identical. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Four daughter cells
Genetically non-identical

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe crossing over and when it occurs. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Homologous chromosomes exchange genetic material
Occurs in prophase I of meiosis

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain independent assortment. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Random orientation of homologous chromosomes at metaphase I
Leads to different combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State two ways meiosis generates genetic variation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Crossing over
Independent assortment
Random fertilisation (if considered)

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Compare mitosis and meiosis in terms of chromosome number and genetic variation. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Mitosis: diploid → diploid, no variation
Meiosis: diploid → haploid, variation introduced
Mitosis produces 2 identical cells, meiosis 4 different cells

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe the structure of an erythrocyte and explain how it relates to its function. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Biconcave shape increases surface area
No nucleus → more space for haemoglobin
Flexible to fit through capillaries

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Give one structural adaptation of neutrophils and its functional significance. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Many lysosomes → digest pathogens
Flexible shape → squeeze through capillary walls

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain how squamous epithelial cells are adapted to their function. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Thin, flat shape → short diffusion distance
Line surfaces such as alveoli for gas exchange

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe two structural features of xylem vessels. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Lignified cell walls for strength
No end walls, forming continuous tubes

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain how phloem sieve tube elements are adapted for transport. [3 marks]

Sieve plates with pores allow flow of sap
Companion cells provide ATP/metabolic support

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State the role of guard cells in plants. [1 mark]

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Define the term 'stem cell'. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Undifferentiated cell capable of division and differentiation

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Distinguish between totipotent and pluripotent stem cells. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Totipotent can form all cell types including extraembryonic tissues
Pluripotent can form most cell types but not extraembryonic tissues

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Give one medical use of stem cells. [1 mark]

Regenerating damaged tissues

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain one ethical concern with embryonic stem cell use. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Involves destruction of embryos

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain the significance of checkpoints in the cell cycle. [2 marks]

Prevent uncontrolled cell division/cancer

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe what happens during anaphase of mitosis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Sister chromatids separate at centromeres
Chromatids pulled to opposite poles by spindle fibres

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: State two processes that occur during telophase. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Nuclear envelopes reform around chromosomes
Chromosomes uncoil to form chromatin

Cells divide uncontrollably forming tumours

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Discuss the importance of stem cells in research. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Model systems to study development
Drug testing on differentiated cells
Study of genetic diseases
Understanding cell specialisation and differentiation

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain how stem cells are used in the treatment of Type 1 diabetes. [3 marks]

Transplanted into pancreas
Restore insulin secretion and blood glucose regulation

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe how meiosis contributes to genetic variation in gametes. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Crossing over exchanges genetic material between homologous chromosomes

Random segregation during anaphase I and II
Results in unique gametes

mark_scheme: G1: cell growth, organelle replication

Essential for evolution and adaptation
